results.title: The Harder they come [DVD]
results.brief_description: The first independent feature film produced in Jamaica gave many Americans their first taste of reggae music with musician Jimmy Cliff in the title role, backed by a fabulous reggae soundtrack. Cliff plays Ivan, a naive rural singer who moves to the city in search of fame but is soon impoverished and exploited by the music industry before becoming embroiled in the trade of marijuana and murder; simultaneously Ivan’s music is released to great acclaim and he becomes somewhat of a local anti-hero. As well as offering a unique view of the reggae scene the milieu of this film also offers a de-romanticised view of seedy Kingston life. Indeed Henzell’s style borders on documentary, as he evokes the squalor of the street, the impoverishment of the people and the multi-faceted systemic corruption. Soundtrack includes the title track as well as other reggae hits “You Can Really Get It if You Want It”, “Sitting in Limbo” and “Johnny Too Bad”. Cast includes Basil Keane, Ras Daniel Hartman, Winston Stona, Janet Barkley, Bobby Charlton and Carl Bradshaw.

results.title: The Happy toilers
results.creator_credit: Keith David Smith and Children's Library and Craft Movement
results.brief_description: An amateur record of the efforts by children attending a crafts centre in a migrant hostel to build their own swimming pool. Made at Bradfield Park Housing Settlement and the Lane Cove National Park.

results.title: Atlantic Adventure cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures and Albert S. Rogell
results.credit_line: ACMI has used best endeavours to remain in contact with the owners of these objects since their deposit with ACMI in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful and ACMI would welcome any information to assist identify a current contact for their ownership.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets: one glass only and the other with slide imagery which has a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: Nancy Carroll Lloyd Nolan Harry Langdon in Atlantic Adventure Not suitable for General Exhibition. A Columbia production There is worn away black handwriting on the plain glass slide which says: Next Wed, Thurs, Fri

results.title: Orchids to You cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Fox Film Corporation and William A. Seiter
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets: one glass only and the other with slide imagery which has a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: John Boles Jean Muir “Orchids to You!” He learned about women from her flowers! Not suitable for general exhibition The two sheets of glass are held together using Gunn’s Slide branded tape: Gunn’s Slide, 9 Collins Place Melb. Cent. 2736,

results.title: The Happy prince
results.brief_description:
Based on an abridged version of the well-known story of “The Happy prince” by Irish writer Oscar Wilde. It tells of the efforts of a statue, the Happy Prince, to bring relief from poverty to the people in his town with the assistance of a dedicated swallow.
This digital video was made with a class of grade 6 students in a small village school in Dromohaire, County Leitrim, Ireland in late 2003-2004, and directed and edited by Michael Buckley. Sue McCauley was creative producer.
The production combined fine art practices and theatrical improvisation with digital media. The whole work was shot in the classroom at the school with backgrounds and animation added through compositing technique to create a visual richness through multi-layering of the imagery. The vision for the project was to make a work for an audience of children, primarily by children using a theatrical, ensemble, improvisational technique. Funded by the Australian Council for the Arts.

results.title: The Happy bachelors = Kuai le de dan shen han
results.creator_credit: Zhou Xiajuan, Song Chong and Shanghai Film Studio
results.brief_description:
The story takes place in the early 1980s. Ms Ding has newly arrived at a ship factory, and she will be the night school teacher there. Her students are a group of bachelors who are attracted by Ding’s beauty but have little interest in her class. They feel ashamed to be taught by such a young lady and believe that they know more than her. However, it proves that they are wrong at work. Workshop leader, Shi Qilong falls in love with Ding and begins to study hard. He seeks help from his friend, Liu Tie, who has been avoiding Ding since she came here. Ding later learns that Liu Tie is her childhood friend, who she has lost contact for years. It turns out that Ding is from a well-off family and her parents were persecuted during the Cultural Revolution. Ding was adopted by Liu’s mum and the two grew up together and liked each other. But after the Cultural Revolutionary, Ding went to university and her parents, without letting their daughter know, told Liu to stop contacting their daughter. Shi learned about their story and encouraged Liu to chase for love. Ding and Liu are finally together and Shi is still a happy bachelor.

This was a popular film in the mid-1980s. Apart from an interesting storyline, the film shows the changed social status of Chinese intellectuals in the 1980s. During the Cultural Revolution (1966-1976), a lot of intellectuals were persecuted and sent to the countryside to be “re-educated” by the peasants. After Deng Xiaoping came to power in the late 1970s, Chinese universities were re-opened to take students, and people started to understand the importance of knowledge. The theme song of the film was popular as well in the mid-1980s. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)

results.title: The Handmaid's tale
results.creator_credit: Volker Schlondorff, Daniel Wilson and Cinecom Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: In the near future, the air and water is poisoned, the result is sterility. Only one out of a hundred women can still bear children and some women stopped, believing there would be no future. The solution; to create an army of ‘handmaids’, an involuntary, semi-religious order of women who exist solely to bear children for the rich, powerful ruling class. Kate (Natasha Richardson) becomes a victim of this cruel and backward world, where women are divided into three kinds, Handmaids, Wives or Prostitutes. A chilling look at a possible future. Based on the novel by Margaret Atwood. Screenplay by Harold Pinter. Cast also includes Victoria Tennant, Faye Dunaway, Elizabeth McGovern, Aidan Quinn and Robert Duvall.

results.title: The Hand that rocks the cradle
results.creator_credit: Roy Darling and Master Tele Films
results.brief_description: A family friend, a journalist, attends a family dinner with his fiancee. A strong clear message emerges that wars could be avoided if women ruled the world.

results.title: The Half-masted schooner
results.creator_credit: Bruce Mackay, Joseph Koenig, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film combining a tuneful ballad with an equally engaging kaleidoscope of pictures, some relating to the story of the song and some not, but all most cheering and amusing to the eye. The soft focus of the live photography and the pleasing patterns of abstract designs combine with the relaxed mood of the ballad to produce an agreeable interlude of sights and sounds. Spawned from the hippy experimental culture of the time.

results.title: The Hairdresser's husband = Le Mari del la coiffeuse
results.creator_credit: Patrice Leconte, TFI and Lambart Productions
results.brief_description: Death is yellow and smells of vanilla pronounces Antoine, the protagonist of this sunny and optimistic film in which even something sombre is imagined as radiant and sweet. Photographed in glowing primary colours, with some scenes shot in slight slow-motion, this study of male erotic obsession is a lazy, dreamy film about nothing more than a state of being - happiness. Cocooned in their little one-roomed store, Antoine and Mathilde, his luminous wife are sufficient to themselves. Two wonderful performances from Jean Rochefort and Anna Galiena are complemented by the Arab music Antoine loves and original music by Michael Nyman.
